results.title: America on the edge of abundance
results.brief_description: Traces America’s snowballing history as an affluent society and looks at the dilemma which abundance brings. A land of abounding factory production and consumption, where success is measured by material standards. America underwent a revolution from an agricultural to an manufacturing society. Now a second revolution looms, to an automated society. What will this mean to the nation, and how individuals will accept a society in which a minority of people can manage the nation’s work, is discussed.

results.title: America in Vietnam
results.creator_credit: Don North, Paul Lang, Ron Kelly, Ian Macleod, Cinequity Funding and Information Television Productions
results.brief_description: A preview of the series “Vietnam: the ten thousand day war”, covering America’s shifting motivations and priorities during three decades of the Vietnam conflict. The conflict became America’s longest, costliest, and most mysterious war and involved five presidencies. Written by Pulitzer Prize winner, Peter Arnett and narrated by Richard Basehart.

results.title: America in the 50's
results.brief_description: America in the 1950’s was a time of catchphrases such as counter culture, Elvis, African American beebop and the Beat Generation. This program looks specifically at Jack Kerouac and the influence of jazz music on his writing; Elvis and the influence of Memphis; the advent of the youth market, and the quest for independence embraced in film, literature and music. Features interviews with B.B King, Jim Dickinson, Billy Walker, Sam Phillips, Joyce Johnson, Sterling Lord, Michael McClure, Alfred Leslie and Maggie Warwick. Narrated by Michael Ontkean.

results.title: America
results.brief_description: Phoebe, Spencer, Felix and Mike have reached a point in their lives where they can no longer call Australia home. Is this due to the fact that they work at All American Videos, where ‘too much is never enough’? It is in this video store that they devise a plan to rob a bank by combining several of their favourite films and create the perfect crime to escape out of their quarter acre black future.

results.creator_credit: Hernan Bornas and Victorian College of the Arts

Is this due to the recurring statement that Australia is the little brother of America, or the fact that they work at “All American Videos, where too much is never enough”? It is in the videostore, a direct representation of American popular culture, that they devise a plan to rob a bank. They use their favourite films as source material to create the perfect crime.

results.title: Amenu's child
results.creator_credit: Sean Graham and Gold Coast Film Unit
results.brief_description: Told in the idiom of an African folk story, this film attempts to encourage native women to seek medical assistance from the local health clinics instead of from witch doctors. Points out that African women are learning the value of modern medicine, but one, Foriwa, was a sceptic and only her child’s death convinced her that the medicine man and the fetish priest, from whom she sought help, had neither the power nor the knowledge to cure her baby. Stresses the importance of practising modern methods of feeding and sanitation as a preventative measure for illness.

results.title: Amelie Ou le Temps D'aimer = Amelia or Time for Love
results.brief_description:
At the end of the 19th century, an orphan girl living near the Mont Saint-Michel island is secretly in love with her cousin Alain. Alain has two passions: the sea and Amelie’s Parisian cousin, Fanny. Realising that her secret love may never be repaid, Amelie slowly loses the will to live.

Credits: Producer, Mina Berard ; director, Michel Drach ; writer, Michel Drach ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Jean-Sebastien Bach.
Cast: Marie-Jose Nat, Jean Sorel, Clotilde Joano, Roger Van Mullem, Jean Babilee, Sophie Daumier, Louise de Vilmorin.

results.title: Amelie [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Jeunet, Arne Meerkamp van Embden, Claudie Ossard, France 3 Cinema, Tapioca Films, Victoires Productions and UGC Images
results.brief_description:
Amelie is the story of a lonely and wistful only child who grows into a woman of yearning and seeks, in minute but effective ways, to improve the lives of those around her. Various eccentrics people the Montmarte district, where Amelie is a waitress; identifying their needs, and those of her neighbours, Amelie sets into motion elaborate plans to (anonymously) relieve their ailments. Amelie’s schemes are both ingenious and creative but she neglects her own desires, in particular her burgeoning romantic feelings for Nino, a patron at her cafe. “Amelie” utilises computer-generated images to reflect the emotional essence of the protagonists’ state and presents a fantastical Montmarte that is awash in glorious colour, markedly absent of graffiti or unsavoury elements. Unlike the previous features of Jean-Pierre Jeunet (Delicatessen, City of lost children), the film’s mise-en-scene works at conveying a light-hearted whimsy about the life of its heroine and her environs, determinedly steering away from the dark side. Whilst “Amelie” is at times shamelessly feel-good, in essence the film works as a fanciful romantic-fantasy, accompanied by a charming soundtrack. Depending on one’s tolerance for cuteness, audiences should find this film a delight, as did the millions who made it a huge hit in France.
Cast includes: Audrey Tatou, Mathieu Kassovitz, Rufus

results.title: Amelia Rose Towers
results.creator_credit: Ashley Scarlett, Nicole Sorby, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: If, as a child, you were picked last for a team. And sought as your refuge a wish or a dream. If you ever felt lonely, peculiar or blue, then Amelia Rose Towers is a bit like you! True! Amelia Rose Towers ‘ whose initials spell ART ‘ faces off against an adversary whose initials spell MAN, after passing through surrealist chambers and screens offering images of a personal identity that can never be reconciled. A story of juggling variables of reality of self and other ; of space, time and perceptions; of the art of science and the science of art but it is also a story of hope, love and courage.
